lead_paragraph: WASHBURN--Seth H. Seth Harwood Washburn, executive, musician, fly fisherman, civil rights advocate and beloved patriarch, died on January 17 in Bath, Maine. He was 94. Seth was born in Kansas City, MO on October 24, 1921, the son of Henrietta DeSelding and Rt. Reverend Benjamin Washburn, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. He married Janet Higginbotham in 1944. Seth attended Dartmouth College, and earned BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from MIT. After serving in the Navy during World War ll, Seth joined Bell Laboratories where he spent his entire career and co-authored "The Design of Switching Circuits," a seminal text in his field. Seth was a fierce advocate for civil rights and fair housing. He was recognized by the Association of Black Laboratories Employees as a "visionary executive, skillful leader, and man of dignity and grace." In 1984, Seth and Janet fulfilled their love for the ocean and the working coast of New England by retiring to Bath. Janet died in 1987. Seth was an accomplished musician, playing piano, flute, and recorder, and had a passion for jazz. His life-long devotion to fly-fishing included tying his own flies for over 70 years. He loved his Newfies, Labs, and Maine Coon cats - and a strong martini and a good cigar. He is survived by five children, ten grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Seth Washburn was an extraordinary man and will be deeply missed by all who knew him. 1/3

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHBURN, SETH H
